[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/ark_serialize.rs] [Function: ark_de()] [Invalid Curve Point Attack] Does the deserialization validate that decoded elliptic curve points lie on the correct BLS12-381 curve, or can an attacker submit points on an invalid curve with weaker discrete log security to break DKG protocols and compromise validator private keys? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/ark_serialize.rs] [Function: ark_de()] [Point at Infinity Bypass] Can an attacker deserialize the point at infinity (identity element) and use it to create invalid DKG shares that pass validation but produce zero secrets, allowing them to compromise distributed key generation and steal validator signing keys? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/ark_serialize.rs] [Function: ark_de()] [Twist Attack] Does the validation prevent accepting points on the quadratic/sextic twist of BLS12-381 G2, which could allow an attacker to perform invalid curve attacks during pairing operations and break BLS signature aggregation in consensus? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/ark_serialize.rs] [Function: ark_de()] [Coordinate Field Validation] Does deserialization verify that point coordinates are within the valid field modulus for BLS12-381, or can out-of-range values cause arithmetic overflows in subsequent cryptographic operations leading to signature forgery? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/ark_serialize.rs] [Function: ark_de()] [Compressed Point Decompression] When decompressing points with Compress::Yes, does the implementation correctly recover the Y-coordinate sign bit, or can bit manipulation allow attackers to deserialize to the negation of intended points, breaking DKG transcript verification? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/ark_serialize.rs] [Function: ark_de()] [Malleability Attack] Can an attacker provide multiple different serialized representations that deserialize to the same point (due to compression or encoding ambiguity), enabling transcript malleability attacks in PVSS protocols that rely on canonical serialization for uniqueness? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/ark_serialize.rs] [Function: ark_de()] [Validation Bypass via Compress Mode] If an attacker forces Compress::No mode during deserialization, does this bypass any security checks that only apply to compressed formats, allowing injection of invalid uncompressed point encodings? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/ark_serialize.rs] [Function: ark_de()] [Buffer Overflow] Can an attacker provide excessively long byte sequences in the Bytes input at line 22 that overflow internal buffers during deserialize_with_mode(), potentially achieving remote code execution on validator nodes? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/ark_serialize.rs] [Function: ark_de()] [Memory Exhaustion DoS] Can an attacker craft malicious serialized data that causes the deserializer to allocate unbounded memory during point reconstruction, leading to OOM crashes that halt consensus or DKG ceremonies? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/ark_serialize.rs] [Function: ark_de()] [Integer Overflow in Size Parsing] Does the deserializer properly validate size prefixes in the byte stream before allocation, or can integer overflows in size calculations lead to heap corruption when processing crafted inputs? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/ark_serialize.rs] [Function: ark_de()] [Use-After-Free] After the Bytes::reader() call at line 23, are there any scenarios where the underlying buffer could be deallocated while the reader is still in use, causing use-after-free vulnerabilities exploitable for RCE? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/ark_serialize.rs] [Function: ark_se()] [Serialization Buffer Overflow] When serializing large elliptic curve points in ark_se() at line 13, can the vec![] buffer overflow if serialize_with_mode() writes more bytes than expected, potentially leaking sensitive key material from adjacent memory? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/ark_serialize.rs] [Function: ark_de()] [Panic in Deserializer] If deserialize_with_mode() panics due to malformed input instead of returning an error at line 23, can an attacker crash validator nodes during DKG by broadcasting panic-inducing payloads, causing consensus liveness failure? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/ark_serialize.rs] [Function: ark_de()] [Error Message Information Leak] Do the error messages returned via map_err at line 24 leak sensitive information about internal cryptographic state or validation logic that attackers could use to refine their attacks? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/ark_serialize.rs] [Function: ark_de()] [Partial Deserialization State] If deserialization fails midway through processing a point, does the implementation properly clean up partial state, or can residual data be exploited in subsequent deserialization attempts?
